posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
For the past few days, I tried to build a CAN sensor using Arduino and MCP2515, achieving good results. Previous attempts on CD to create custom CAN systems lacked sufficient documentation, motivating me to share my efforts.

Achievements include:
- Connecting analog signals from Arduino to RoboRIO
- Implementing digital inputs from Arduino to RoboRIO
- Setting up a REV colour sensor V3 with fault detection capability
- Controlling RoboRIO digital outputs
- Using a PWM servo controller (illegal for FIRST Robotics Competition)
- Detecting RoboRIO heartbeats directly from Arduino

While aiming to contribute to the CAN ecosystem, I note that updates to SystemCore may render previous CAN-based projects obsolete. I recommend using a CAN analyzer like the CANalyst-II or the CANable software for monitoring CAN frames. Both options offer benefits; the former is widely available, while the latter provides built-in CAN monitoring within the Arduino simulator. For those interested, a dedicated Custom-CAN channel on our Discord server offers ongoing support and updates.

This project aims to foster new ideas in the FIRST Robotics Community regarding CAN implementation.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: The most important part of having your robot interface with roboRIO is figuring out the message ID. According to the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) specifications, a message ID consists of multiple pieces of information, including the device number and API ID. Understanding this is crucial when comparing the FRC CAN bus implementation to others. The FRC documentation provides detailed insights into CAN addressing and related concepts. By using Python and a CAN analyzer beforehand, I created a simulator to test different configurations, making the process smoother once the message ID functionality is understood. Additionally, it's vital to configure the CAN bus correctly; failing to set it to 1 Mbps can disrupt the entire network and render the analyzer ineffective.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked:
This is excellent!

Is there any reason you use a Timer for polling instead of making the ArduinoCAN extend SubsystemBase and read the packets in periodic()?

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: There were multiple trials and errors, including ChatGPT and copy-paste operations, in the process.... However, the CAN Controller Area Network is asynchronous, meaning regardless of what RoboRIO is doing, the controller on the other end keeps sending data. Unfortunately, using `can.readPacketLatest()` only provides the most recent frame, unlike the Python-can notifier which operates within an event loop or creates threads to distribute messages. To overcome this limitation, we developed a workaround to retrieve CAN data at a higher frequency in cases where the system experiences loop overrun.

link_counts.title: Notifier and Listeners - python-can 4.5.1.dev11+g5d62394 documentation

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, `CAN.readPacketLatest()` only gives the most recent frame. In many use cases, this is fine (and desired). Instead of actively polling for messages and updating member variables in a separate thread, you could retrieve the latest message in the getter functions and extract the data at that point. If reading every message matching a given message ID and mask is actually desired, you can use the CAN stream functions. These don't have quite as nice an API on the Java side but will allow you to read every message without high rate polling.

link_counts.title: CANJNI (WPILib API 2025.3.2)

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
I just completed an update to REVColourSensorV3.  
I defined several constants including DEVICE_ID MANUFACTURER_ID DEVICE_NUMBER STATUS_API_ID COLOR_SENSOR_API_ID CONTROL_API_ID DT7_API1_ID DT7_API2_ID DT7_API3_ID and HEARTBEAT_ID.  
I created a function called makeCANMsgID to generate unique message IDs based on device parameters. I used this function to calculate the following CAN IDs: STATUS_ID COLOR_SENSOR_ID CONTROL_ID DT7_FRAME1_ID DT7_FRAME2_ID and DT7_FRAME3_ID.  

Additionally I developed a GUI tool designed to assist in generating these CAN message IDs according to the FIRST Robotics Competition and Controller Area Network specifications.  

An image illustrating the setup is available at https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/4X/2/c/c/2cc3d3848fc661e0a20ec807c0d7ac71535c2d75.png.  

The following constants remain unchanged as per the ROBO RIO configuration: DEVICE_ID and MANUFACTURER_ID.  

It is crucial to initialize the CAN communication on ROBO RIO correctly by setting the deviceManufacturer and deviceType variables during object instantiation. Currently these values are set to defaults suitable for ROBO RIO functionality.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: The roboRIO driver is mostly completed, capable of reading battery information and communicating with an Arduino via CAN. According to the FRC Can Spec documentation, the heartbeat includes time and date fields, which should correspond to the actual time of day. However, during decoding, particularly in practice mode, these fields appear as a countdown timer. The author is unsure whether connecting to the Field Management System (FMS) would resolve this discrepancy. An additional inquiry is made to @Ryan_Blue for further assistance.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. The text is: "Itâ€™s here! I got this mostly working, only some minor bugfix! An ESP32 CAN enabled Addressable LED Controller! Fully customizable!" "This controller have support of built-in pattern or pixel by pixel update from roboRIO." Please read the full documentation for how to set it up and how to create your own pattern! Be very careful with pixel by pixel mode (Mode 255) as it could create a huge amount of CAN traffic (45% CAN util for 60 pixel). It is recommended that you create your own pattern in ESP32 and call it using mode setting instead of doing pixel by pixel update from roboRIO. (Log below is a rainbow pattern that utilizes all 8 messages)
"
